newsitem.title: USA: Indiana police arrest alleged drug dealer-parolee.
newsitem.headline: Indiana police arrest alleged drug dealer-parolee.

text.p: Police said Tuesday Ollie Smithey should have been in prison when officers raided the alleged drug-dealer's opulent home, equipped with hot tub, wall-size television and video surveillance system.
But Smithey, 61, was paroled from an Illinois prison in 1989 after serving four years of an 18-year sentence, and never returned to Louisiana to serve out a 297-year sentence there.
"He was running free when he should have been in prison," Hammond narcotics detective John Doughty said. "He was living the life of luxury in the guise of home improvement."
Police alleged that Smithey had been operating a $20,000-per-week marijuana-selling operation and laundering the proceeds through a phony contracting business.

In 1983, Smithey was convicted of several armed robberies in Louisiana and began serving three consecutive 99-year sentences, but he was shipped to Illinois a year later to face trial in Rockford for armed robbery and home invasion.
But after he served the Illinois sentence, Louisiana apparently withdrew its warrant to have him returned, Illinois authorities said.
"My guess is we notified Louisiana and never heard back from them. Only God knows what happened," Illinois prison spokesman Nic Howell said of Smithey's premature freedom.

In Tuesday's raid on Smithey's home, which contained photographs of him cavorting with models, a room with a pool table and a huge fish tank, police said they found four ounces of marijuana, along with suspected cocaine and heroin.
